case_name: Ajantha Transports P Ltd v. Regional Transport Authority

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1402 of 1974 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated 30th April 1974 of the Madras High Court in C. Revsn. Petn. No. 576 of 1974.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and order dated the 30th April 1974 of the Madras High Court in C. Revsn. Petn. No. 576 of 1974.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1402 of 1974 arises out of fourteen applications considered on 29th December 1971 by the Regional Transport Authority, Coimbatore, for grant of stage carriage permit on route Coimbatore to Sathyamangalam.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1402 of 1974 arises out of fourteen applications, including that of the appellant before Lis, Ajantha Transports  P  Ltd which were companysidered on 29th December 1971 by the Regional Transport Authority, Coimbatore, for the grant of a stage carriage permit to ply an additional bus on the route from Coimbatore to Sathyamangalam via Koilpalayam and some other places.

facts.text: Five applications rejected by RTA Coimbatore on preliminary ground that prescribed fees had not been paid.

anchor.surface_text: Five of these were rejected on the preliminary ground that the prescribed fees had number been paid.

facts.text: One application withheld from consideration by RTA for want of Income-tax Clearance certificate.

anchor.surface_text: One was withheld from companysideration for want of Income-tax Clearance certificate.

facts.text: One applicant disqualified under Section 62A of Motor Vehicles Act by RTA because already had more than ten permits.

anchor.surface_text: One applicant was found disqualified, under Section 62 A  c  of the Motor Vehicle Act as amended by the Tamil Nadu Amendment Act 16 of 1971. because lie already had more than ten permits.

facts.text: Palaniappa Gounder obtained highest 9 marks but bypassed in favour of Ajantha Transports P Ltd with 8.69 marks because Gounder granted permit on 8th October 1971.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the remaining seven applicants, the highest scorer, according to the marking system adopted by the Regional Transport Authority of the region, was one Palaniappa Gounder who obtained nine marks. But, Gounder was by-passed in favour of the appellant who secured 8.69 marks because Gounder had already been granted a permit on 8th October 1971.

facts.text: Three appeals preferred to State Transport Appellate Tribunal against RTA resolution, including by Gounder.

anchor.surface_text: Three appeals, including one by Gounder were then preferred to the State Transport Appellate Tribunal against the Regional Transport Authoritys resolution.

facts.text: Only appeal of P.V.K. Transports succeeded before State Transport Appellate Tribunal despite 7.42 marks vs 8.69 of Ajantha.

anchor.surface_text: Only the appeal of P. V. K. Transports, described as the second appellant, succeeded, although this party was awarded only 7.42 marks as against 8.69 of the appellant before Lis.

facts.text: Parties did not dispute correctness of marks assigned under various heads.

anchor.surface_text: It appears, from the order of the State Transport Tribunal, that the parties did number dispute the companyrectness of the marks actually assigned under various heads.

facts.text: P.V.K. Transports obtained third permit on 31st July 1971.

anchor.surface_text: Firstly, the respondent was a recent grantee on the date of meeting, it aaying obtained its third permit on 31st Jul,, 1971, about five months prior to it.

facts.text: P.V.K. Transports only permit obtained on 8th December 1970.

anchor.surface_text: The 2nd appellan ts only permit was got by it on 8th December 1970.

facts.text: Madras High Court rejected Ajantha Transports revision petition under Section 115 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Madras had rejected the Ajantha Transports Revision Petition under Section 115 of the Civil Procedure companye which was made applicable to decisions of the Tribunal by the Tamil Nadu Motor Vehicle Amendment Act 16 of 1971.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2254 of 1969 from judgment dated 17th September 1969 of Madras High Court in Second Appeal No. 282 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPEAL NO. 2254 OF 1969 Appeal from the Judgment and order dated the 17th September 1959 of the Madras High Court in Second Appeal No. 282 of 1969.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2254 of 1969 arises out of twenty one applications before RTA South Arcot, Cuddalore for permit Porto-Novo to Puliyangudi.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 2254 of 1969 arises out of twenty one applications which came up for companysideration before the Regional Transport Authority. South Arcot, Cuddalore, for grant of a stage carriage permit for- the route from Porto- Novo to Puliyangudi.

facts.text: RTA South Arcot rejected five applications from new entrants without previous experience.

anchor.surface_text: The R. T. A. rejected five applications on the ground that they were from new entrants who had numberprevious experience of this business,

facts.text: Joint applicants Chettiar and Another preferred over Natarajan by RTA because better route knowledge and Natarajan recent grantee.

anchor.surface_text: The joint applicants Chettiar and Another at No. 6 were preferred to Natarajan, applicant No. 13, on two grounds firstly, the applicants at No. 6 were companysidered as somewhat better acquainted with the routes and, secondly, the applicant No. 13 had secured a recent grant of a permit on another route.

facts.text: State Transport Appellate Tribunal preferred Kannon Motor Transport P Ltd as local enterprise.

anchor.surface_text: It preferred the claim of Karmen Motor Transport  P  Ltd., principally on the ground that it was a local enterprise. of persons residing along the route.

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1481 to 1483 of 1970 from judgments dated 9th October 1969 of Madras High Court in W. Appeal Nos. 437-439 of 1969.

facts.text: 42 applications made to RTA South Arcot for permit Chidambaram to Tirukoilur.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1481-1483 of 1970 have resulted from 42 applications made for the grant of a permit to ply on the route Chidambaram to Tirukoilur via Vedalur, Kadampuliyur, Panruti, and some other places, by the Regional Transport Authority, South Arcot.

facts.text: RTA South Arcot granted permit to Ms. Prabhu Transport P Ltd on 23rd December 1965 finding superior qualifications.

anchor.surface_text: The R. T. A. found, on 23rd December 1965, the qualifications of M s. Prabhu Transports  P  Ltd., to be superior, to those of its rivals and ordered the grant of the permit to it.

arguments.claim: Permit grant quasi-judicial; must consider relevant, ignore irrelevant; irrelevant ground or ignoring relevant = material irregularity under s115 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: If a ground which is irrelevant is taken into account with others which are relevant, or, a relevant ground, which exists, is unjustifiably ignored, it companyld be said to be a case of exercise of power under Sec. 47 of the Act, which is quasi- judicial, in a manner which suffers from a material irregularity.

arguments.claim: Recent grant/ other permits by itself neither qualification nor disqualification; relevant only if linked by other facts to public interest.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, it will be seen that, by itself, a recent grant or the possession of other permits is neither a qualification number a disqualification divorced from other circumstances which companyld indicate how such a fact is related to the interests of the public generally.

arguments.claim: Where everything equal, prefer non-recent grantee per equality (Art14).

anchor.surface_text: in cases where everything else is absolutely equal as between two applicants... it companyld be said that an application of principle of equality of opportunity, which companyld be companyered by Article 14, may enable a person who is number a fresh gran- tee to obtain a preference.

arguments.claim: Viable unit rule (rule155A): marks for each stage carriage up to 4 to build unit of 5; recent grant not demerit by itself.

anchor.surface_text: Viable Unit The applicant who operates number more than four stage carriages excluding spare buses, shall be awarded marks at the rate of one mark for each stage carriage in order to have a viable unit of five carriages excluding spare buses.

arguments.claim: Division Bench correctly remanded for considering impact of multiple grants on public interest.

anchor.surface_text: The Division Bench had sent back the case to the Appellate Tribunal, without determining the rights of the parties... mere fact that two views companyld be taken... number justify interference under Art136.

arguments.claim: HC rightly remanded CA1481-83 as permits granted to one party without sufficient discrimination grounds; quasi-judicial must be fair/impartial.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court seems to us to have rightly hinted that, where the results of exercise of power to grant permit shows that permits are, without sufficient grounds for a discrimination or preference based on an appraisement of merits or requirements of public interest, being invariably granted to one particular party the powers are number fairly or impartially exercised.

holdings.text: by itself, a recent grant or the possession of other permits is neither a qualification nor a disqualification divorced from other circumstances which could indicate how such a fact is related to the interests of the public generally.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, it will be seen that, by itself, a recent grant or the possession of other permits is neither a qualification nor a disqualification divorced from other circumstances which could indicate how such a fact is related to the interests of the public generally.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 47 requires all considerations to relate to public interest; isolated facts like recent grant lack nexus unless linked by other circumstances showing impact on public.

holdings.text: The relevance of the previous possession or grant of a permit appears only when other facts and circumstances, connecting it with and showing either the adverse or beneficial effects of its impact, in a particular case, on the interests of the public, are shown to exist.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Nexus to public interest under s47(1)(a) required; weight depends on totality of circumstances.

holdings.text: Unless and until these other facts and circumstances, indicating the nexus or connection with public interest, appear, such a fact, by itself, should not affect an application for a permit.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Mechanical application without public interest link invalid; no automatic disqualification or preference.

holdings.text: Consideration of matters which are not relevant to or are foreign to the scope of powers conferred by Section 47 will vitiate the grant of a permit under Section 47.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, decisions of this Court have made it clear that an exercise of the permit issuing power, under Section 47 of the Act, must rest on facts and circumstances relevant for decision on the question of public interest, which has to be always placed in the fore-front in considering applications for grant of permits. Consideration of matters which are not relevant to or are foreign to the scope  if powers conferred by Section 47 will vitiate the grant of a permit under Section 47.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s47 limits to public interest; foreign considerations violate Art14/19(1)(g); precedents confirm.

holdings.text: If a ground which is irrelevant is taken into account with others which are relevant, or, a relevant ground, which exists, is unjustifiably ignored, it would be said to be a case of exercise of power under Sec. 47 of the Act, which is quasi-judicial, in a manner which suffers from a material irregularity.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Quasi-judicial duty requires relevant considerations only; error triggers s115 CPC revision.

holdings.text: permit issuing power under Section 47 is restricted to service of interests of the public generally in a broad enough sense to include due respect for guaranteed fundamental rights of citizens.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we hold that permit issuing power under Section, 47 is restricted to service of interests of the public generally in a broad enough sense to include due respect for guaranteed fundamental rights of citizens.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s47(1)(a) incorporates Art14/19(1)(g); cannot exceed constitutional limits.

holdings.text: the provisions of Section 47(1)(e) of the Act in their application to Madras were intact at the time of the grant.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Ordinances repealed by Acts 10 & 16/1971; no omission.

holdings.text: Clause F of sub-rule 3 of rule 155-A... should, therefore, have been taken into account, and, unless there was good enough reason to depart from it, the rule should have been followed.

anchor.surface_text: Clause F of sub-rule 3 of rule 155-A, set out above, should, therefore., have been taken into account, and, unless there was good enough reason to depart from it, the rule should have been followed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Valid rules under s133 part of s47 considerations; viable unit marks for efficiency.

holdings.text: The order of the Appellate Tribunal was, in our opinion, vitiated by a material irregularity. The High Court should, therefore, have interfered even in the exercise of its power under Section 115 Civil Procedure Code which has been made applicable to such cases.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Mechanical use of recent grant/three permits, ignoring viable unit and no public interest nexus.

holdings.text: the High Court was in error in granting the certificate when nothing was decided by their judgment. The order was not final.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No final determination of rights; remand order interlocutory (citing Raman & Raman).

holdings.text: where the results of exercise of power to grant permit shows that permits are, without sufficient grounds for a discrimination or preference based on an appraisement of merits or requirements of public interest, being invariably granted to one particular party the powers are not fairly or impartially exercised.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Quasi-judicial exercise must be fair; pattern of favoritism indicates irregularity.

anchor.surface_text: In W P No. 120/71 and 2028/71 the Madras High Court has upheld the judgment of the Tribunal Preferring a single permit holder as against a two permit holder  vide also Judgment in WP No. 482/ 71 .

precedents.cited_proposition: Madras High Court upheld judgment preferring single permit holder over two permit holder

anchor.surface_text: Thus, decisions of this Court have made it clear that an exercise of the permit issuing power, under Section 47 of the Act, must rest on facts and circumstances relevant for decision on the question of public interest, which has to be always placed in the fore-front in considering applications for grant of permits. Consideration of matters which are not relevant to or are foreign to the scope  if powers conferred by Section 47 will vitiate the grant of a permit under Section 47.
